title: Don't five-paragraph essays typically argue three unique points? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m not sure what you mean by “unique”. The absolute classic standardized no-imagination no-freedom version of the 5-graf essay is Introduction: some reason for the reader to be interested, ending in thesis statement Body 1: Although some people say …. summary of evidence AGAINST the thesis Body 2: In fact, Actually, In the real world, etc. …. why the evidence against the thesis is fallacious, untrue, irrelevant, or trivial, leading into what the real evidence is Body 3: Why the important evidence shows that the thesis is right Conclusion: Therefore … thesis restatement … and why that matters, often referring to the reason for interest in the introduction. I didn’t enjoy teaching it and student writing it produced was generally dull, but it did seem to improve student writing. Kind of like doing dull calisthenics so that you can play an interesting sport.

They do, an introductory paragraph followed by three body paragraphs and a fifth concluding paragraph. The word “unique” isn’t quite appropriate since the three body paragraphs all develop separate points that, in themselves, support the thesis or controlling idea that you set out in your opening paragraph.
When tutoring students I use this to help visualize the idea.
